title: Hunter Greene’s return to Reds rotation might push Chase Burns to the bullpen
description: Regardless of the role Burns is in, the Reds are hoping Burns is pitching for the team the rest of the season.
content:
CINCINNATI — With the return of Hunter Greene to the rotation, the Cincinnati Reds have six starters for five spots, which could move rookie Chase Burns to the bullpen.

Regardless of the role Burns is in, the Reds are hoping Burns is pitching for the team the rest of the season. Between the minors and majors this season, Burns has already surpassed the 100 innings he threw in his junior year at Wake Forest.

“We’re all in agreement that we do not want this kid stopping pitching,” Reds manager Terry Francona said before Monday’s 4-1 loss against the Philadelphia Phillies. “So how we get to the end? We might have to get a little creative.”

When the Reds acquired starter Zack Littell at the trade deadline, the plan was to move right-hander Nick Martinez to the bullpen and then maybe have Burns join him once Greene was ready.

Greene is now ready, scheduled to make his first start in more than two months in Wednesday’s series finale against the Phillies. Martinez, who picked up his 10th win of the season Saturday in Pittsburgh, will start Friday’s series-opener against the National League Central-leading Milwaukee Brewers.

That means Burns could be the man headed to the bullpen, giving the Reds a legitimate weapon late in games. Burns, 22, has struck out 10 batters in four of his last five starts, with the lone exception coming in the start at Bristol Motor Speedway when the game was postponed in the bottom of the first inning. Burns struck out two of the three batters he faced in that game, before taking the hill again on Friday in Pittsburgh.

As a starter, Burns has been mixing in a changeup that is a pitch he’ll need as a starter, but in the bullpen he’ll be able to rely on his 100-mph fastball and his devastating slider. He could slide in behind closer Emilio Pagán and setup man Tony Santillan to bolster the back of the Reds’ bullpen.

Francona said he and pitching coach Derek Johnson talked to Burns about the possibility earlier on Monday.

Burns will eventually move to the bullpen, but the question now is when? That’s something Francona said hasn’t been decided.

“Not yet,” Francona said before Monday’s game. “No official updates yet.”

Burns didn’t pitch at all last year after the Reds drafted him, but burned through the team’s minor leagues after starting the season at High-A Dayton. At Dayton, Double-A Chattanooga and Triple-A Louisville, Burns threw 66 total innings. Since his debut on June 24, Burns has thrown 34 1/3 innings over eight starts, going 0-3 with a 5.24 ERA, but has struck more than a third of the batters he’s faced, with 57 strikeouts against 151 batters faced.

The Reds, though, are not looking at a hard innings cap, Francona said.

“There’s an ‘-ish,’” Francona said in relation to the target number of innings for Burns. “I think that can be a little cosmetic. You watch how the kid’s throwing and also let the pitching guys and the trainers and the medical people use their judgment.”

Many of Burns’ outings in the minors were on pitch counts, leading to longer outings than maybe would be suggested by his pitch counts. He was also so dominant (89 strikeouts against 13 walks) that there were few stressful innings on his way through the minors.

That hasn’t necessarily been the case in the big leagues.

Burns gave up five earned runs in his second start, at Boston on June 30, but was tipping his pitches. Taking that game out of the equation, he’s only allowed one other earned run in the first three innings of those seven starts. Even including the game against the Red Sox, batters are hitting just .203/.288/.305 against him the first time through the order. The second time hitters see him, they’re hitting .327/.377/.633.

Greene, who was taken by the Reds with the second pick in the 2017 draft, will make his first start in more than two months Wednesday in the Reds’ series finale against the Phillies. Greene went on the injured list with a right groin strain after his start on June 3 and hadn’t pitched in the big leagues since then.

Burns was expected to go to the bullpen when Greene returned, but that was before lefty Nick Lodolo went on the IL with a blister on his left index finger. Lodolo is throwing smooth plyo balls to keep his arm in shape without dealing with the seams of the baseball that contribute to the blister.

Martinez made a relief appearance last week in Chicago before earning his 10th win of the season Saturday in Pittsburgh, allowing just one run on four hits over seven innings.

Leaving Martinez in the rotation would allow Burns to pitch deeper into the season and perhaps in the postseason, if the Reds were to qualify. Martinez would return to the bullpen when Lodolo was ready. Of course, there’s a lot of things that could happen between now and then.

For now, Greene is starting Wednesday, followed by Martinez on Friday. Beyond that, nothing is set in stone.
summary: The return of Hunter Greene to the Cincinnati Reds' rotation could push rookie Chase Burns to the bullpen due to the team's six starters for five spots, potentially forcing Burns to drop into the bullpen. The Reds hope Burns will continue pitching for the rest of the season, as he has already surpassed the 100 innings he threw in his junior year at Wake Forest. The team's manager, Terry Francona, and pitching coach Derek Johnson have discussed the possibility of Burns' move to the back of the team’s bullpen. Burns has struck out 10 batters in four of his last five starts and has only allowed one earned run in seven starts. Despite this, the Reds are not looking at a hard innings cap for Burns, as manager Franconia said it hasn't been decided yet.
shortSummary: The return of Hunter Greene to the Cincinnati Reds could push Chase Burns to the bullpen, enhancing the team's late-game capabilities.
argos_summary: The Cincinnati Reds are facing a decision regarding rookie Chase Burns as they welcome back Hunter Greene to their rotation, creating a surplus of six starters for five spots. Manager Terry Francona indicated that Burns may transition to the bullpen to bolster late-game options, despite his strong performance as a starter. Greene is set to make his return from injury, while Nick Martinez, who recently earned his 10th win, will also remain in the rotation for now, leaving the future roles of Burns and Martinez uncertain.
